metadata.title: Dehydrogenation of butenes over copper oxide supported on alumina under anaerobic conditions: Bifunctionality of the catalyst
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Graphical abstract CuO/Al2O3 was used for dehydrogenation of butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) to 1,3-butadiene at 200°C under an anaerobic condition without an excessive amount of dilution. 1,3-butadiene was selectively obtained from butenes without the formation of carbon oxides over the CuO/Al2O3 catalyst. Bifunctionality of oxidation and C−H bond activation by CuO and Al2O3, respectively, were strongly required for the selective conversion of the butenes to 1,3-butadiene. Keywords Anaerobic dehydrogenation Butenes 1,3-Butadiene CuO/Al2O3 1 Introduction 1,3-Butadiene is a primary skeletal building block for synthetic rubber and has been used widely in the manufacturing of a large number of chemical products [1,2]. Over 95% of butadiene is produced as a byproduct of ethylene production from steam cracking. However, the demand for 1,3-butadiene is increasing rapidly and on-purpose routes (i.e., dehydrogenation technology) that can boost the production of 1,3-butadiene are strongly required in the petrochemical industry. There have been two approaches of direct dehydrogenation and oxidative dehydrogenation to produce 1,3-butadiene from butenes [3–7], but they should be advanced technically due to the following problems. The direct dehydrogenation of butene is a fairly simple and attractive route to produce 1,3-butadiene. However, controlling undesirable side reactions such as butene cracking and coke formation over the catalyst surface can complicate the formation process [8–13]. The endothermic characteristic requiring additional heat during the reaction is another disadvantage, and the maximum yield for 1,3-butadiene is limited when a thermodynamic equilibrium point is reached. In order to circumvent the problems of direct dehydrogenation, exothermic oxidative dehydrogenation has been suggested. However, it is difficult to conduct the oxidative dehydrogenation of butene to 1,3-butadiene selectively without a loss of the hydrocarbon feed due to the complete oxidation to CO2, especially in a concentrated feed composition without dilution. This remains a quite challenging issue when attempting to use oxidative dehydrogenation to produce 1,3-butadiene selectively without the formation of carbon oxides. In this work, to induce a more selective dehydrogenation process, the dehydrogenation of butenes was carried out under anaerobic conditions over a supported oxide catalyst having bifunctionality (redox-coupling of active metal oxide and isomerization of its supporting material). In order to monitoring the initial catalytic performance, the yield of 1,3-butadiene and carbon oxide according to the depletion of lattice oxygen was examined using a gas chromatograph equipped with a trapping multi-position valve. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Alumina (γ-Al2O3, 2.5mm, sphere type, Sasol co.) and silica (SiO2, 0.1–0.18mm, sphere type, Sigma–Aldrich) were used as a supporting material. Cobalt oxide, copper oxide, iron oxide, manganese oxide, and nickel oxide were chosen as an active metal oxide. Each metal oxide was loaded on alumina by an incipient wetness impregnation method. Cobalt nitrate hydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), copper nitrate hydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), iron nitrate hydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), manganese nitrate hydrate (Mn(NO3)2·6H2O), and nickel nitrate hydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) were used as a metal oxide precursor, respectively. Metal oxide content was controlled to be 10wt% in all cases. The typical procedure for the preparation of copper oxide loaded on alumina catalyst is as follows. A known amount of copper nitrate hydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) was dissolved in distilled water. The aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was impregnated onto Alumina (γ-Al2O3) through incipient wetness method. The impregnated solid was dried at room temperature for 12h and it was dried overnight in a 120°C oven and then calcined at 550°C in static air for 6h to obtain 10wt% CuO/Al2O3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Crystalline phases of the catalysts were confirmed by XRD measurements (Rigaku MiniflexII) using Cu Kα radiation operated at 30kV and 15mA. TPR and TPO experiments were carried out in a Micromeritics Autochem II to investigate the redox ability of the catalyst. 0.25g of each catalyst was charged into a quartz reactor of the TPR/TPO apparatus. 10% H2/Ar mixed gas was used at a flow rate of 50ml/min for TPR experiment. Then, TPO was conducted with 5% O2/He mixed gas at a flow rate of 50ml/min. In both cases, the temperature was raised from 50 to 600°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min. The uptake amounts of hydrogen and oxygen were detected using a TCD. TPR/TPO cycle was repeated several times. The second cycle result was used because the result did not change after the second cycle. 2.3 Dehydrogenation of butenes Gas phase reactions were carried out in plug flow reactors. A mixed stream of butene, N2, and He was introduced into the reactor at a total flow rate of 30ml/min. The molar ratio of butene:N2:He was controlled to be 1:1:1. 1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene were separately used as butene feed. The catalyst bed consisted of 6g of catalyst (non-diluted and held in place with a glass frit) and the reaction was conducted at a furnace temperature of 200°C and nominally at atmospheric pressure. The reaction was continued until the catalyst had no activity for the desired product, and the catalyst was regenerated at 500°C for 30min under a flow of air (100ml/min). After cooling the catalyst, the reaction was carried out again at 200°C under the same gas composition and flow rate as the first reaction. This reused reaction result was reported in this work since the repeated reactions didn’t show any differences after the second reaction, even if the catalytic test and the regeneration were repeated several times. Reactant and product concentrations were measured using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890N) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Conversion of butene and selectivity for 1,3-butadiene were calculated according to the following equations. Yield for 1,3-butadiene was calculated by multiplying conversion of butene and selectivity for 1,3-butadiene. C o n v e r s i o n o f b u t e n e = n b u t e n e , i n − n b u t e n e , o u t n b u t e n e , i n S e l e c t i v i t y f o 1,3 − b u t a d i e n e = n 1,3 − b u t a d i e n e , o u t n b u t e n e , i n − n b u t e n e , o u t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selection of oxygen carrier and support: Dehydrogenation of 1-butene over MO x /Al2O3 (M=Co, Cu, Fe, Mn, and Ni) and CuO/SiO2 Copper oxide was chosen as an active metal oxide for redox-coupling in the dehydrogenation of 1-butene because CuO/Al2O3 showed the highest yield for 1,3-butadiene among MO x /Al2O3 (M=Co, Cu, Fe, Mn, and Ni), as shown in Fig. 1 . Conversion of 1-butene as well as selectivity for 1,3-butadiene varied significantly with changing metal oxide, because each metal oxide has a different redox property and a unique interaction with alumina. Cobalt oxide and nickel oxide showed high conversion of 1-butene, while no 1,3-butadiene was formed. Isomerization of 1-butene only occurred by alumina. On the other hand, copper oxide, iron oxide, and manganese oxide generated 1,3-butadiene. Selectivity for 1,3-butadiene was different considerably. Among the catalysts tested, CuO/Al2O3 showed the highest selectivity and yield for 1,3-butadiene. Al2O3 and SiO2 were used as a supporting material to examine the effect of the supporting material. In both cases, copper content was held at 10wt%. The oxidation state of copper oxide species determined from XRD patterns was CuO (Fig. 2 ). Fig. 3 shows the catalytic performance of CuO/Al2O3 and CuO/SiO2 in the dehydrogenation of 1-butene at various temperatures. Both CuO/Al2O3 and CuO/SiO2 catalysts showed that conversion of 1-butene increased with increasing the reaction temperature, while yield for 1,3-butadiene reached its maximum point at a certain temperature since selectivity for 1,3-butadiene decreased with increasing the temperature (Fig. 4 ). Yield for 1,3-butadiene over CuO/Al2O3 was highest at 200°C, whereas CuO/SiO2 showed the highest yield for 1,3-butadiene at 300°C. This result was closely related to the redox property of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 5 . TPR peak temperature of CuO/SiO2 (221°C) was higher than that of CuO/Al2O3 (141°C). Moreover, CuO/SiO2 showed higher TPO peak temperatures than CuO/Al2O3, indicating that CuO/Al2O3 has a better redox property than CuO/SiO2 and the redox property of copper oxide is strongly affected by the supporting material. Al2O3 and SiO2 without copper oxide were also used for the dehydrogenation of 1-butene, in order to investigate the effect of the supporting materials on this reaction. These results are shown in Fig. 3. Only isomerization reaction occurred without the generation of 1,3-butadiene, indicating that copper oxide is required for the production of 1,3-butadiene. Moreover, the yields for 1,3-butadiene over CuO/Al2O3 and CuO/SiO2 were related to the catalytic activities of Al2O3 and SiO2 in the isomerization reaction. Alumina and treated alumina have been widely studied as catalysts for use in the isomerization of butenes because the acidic or basic sites of alumina work well during the isomerization reaction [14]. It has been also reported that some of the isomerization activity of silica is due to its impurities and surface hydroxyl groups [15]. Conversion of 1-butene over both Al2O3 and SiO2 increased with increasing the temperature. However, the conversion over Al2O3 was higher than that over SiO2 and the increase in the conversion over Al2O3 began at a much lower temperature as well. This result implies that Al2O3 has better catalytic activity for the isomerization of 1-butene than SiO2 and the enhanced yield for 1,3-butadiene over CuO/Al2O3 is closely related to the higher isomerization activity of the Al2O3 support. 3.2 Dehydrogenation of butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) For a better understanding of the effect of the isomerization activity of CuO/Al2O3 to produce 1,3-butadiene, the dehydrogenation of 1-butene and 2-butene isomers (cis- and trans-) was carried out. These results are summarized in Table 1 . 1,3-butadiene was formed from all types of butene tested. It was also observed that butenes could be converted to other types of butene regardless of the type. The activity and selectivity differed depending on the butene type. 1-butene showed a higher yield for 1,3-butadiene than cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene because 1-butene has a higher 1,3-butadiene formation rate than cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene [16]. Al2O3 without copper oxide was also used for the dehydrogenation reaction (Table 1). Isomerization reactions only occurred without the formation of 1,3-butadiene. It is interesting to note that the mole fractions of butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) after the reaction were nearly identical regardless of the reactant type. They were approximately 14, 32, and 54%, respectively, at all times when Al2O3 was used for the reaction at 200°C, even if the reactant was switched. To explain this result, we calculated the theoretical equilibrium composition of 1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene at 200°C. The equilibrium mole fractions were 13.5, 34.6, and 51.9%, respectively. The calculated equilibrium mole fractions were almost identical to the measured mole fractions after the reaction. This indicates that butene isomerization over Al2O3 at 200°C nearly reached an equilibrium state, indicating that Al2O3 has remarkable catalytic activity for the isomerization of butenes. 10wt% CuO/SiO2 was also used for the dehydrogenation of butenes (Table 1). Conversion of butenes over CuO/SiO2 was very low because SiO2 had almost no acidic and basic sites and it could not isomerize butenes well. This indicates that the isomerization activity is related to the butene activation capability and it can affect the catalytic activity of the dehydrogenation of butenes. 3.3 Role of CuO and Al2O3 in dehydrogenation of butenes We confirmed earlier that the redox property of the catalyst is very importantly related to the catalytic activity during the dehydrogenation of butenes. It was also observed that the oxygen of copper oxide was consumed during the reaction. For a further examination of role of copper oxide during the dehydrogenation reaction, the CuO/Al2O3 used was regenerated at various temperatures and applied to the dehydrogenation reaction. When the catalyst oxidized at 100°C was used, isomerization reactions mainly occurred due to alumina because copper is scarcely oxidized at 100°C (Fig. 5). The yield for 1,3-butadiene increased with increasing the oxidation temperature (Fig. 6 ). This indicates that as more copper is oxidized, more 1,3-butadiene is formed, indicating that the oxygen of copper oxide is required to produce 1,3-butadiene. In addition, H2O production during the reaction was monitored by a quadrupole mass spectrometer system. As shown in Fig. 7 , H2O was formed during the reaction, and its signal increased with an increase in the oxidation temperature. Considering that the selectivity of CO2 at 200°C is negligible (Fig. 4), this implies that most of the oxygen of copper oxide was used to generate H2O during the dehydrogenation of butenes. It was revealed that both copper oxide and alumina are needed for the dehydrogenation of butenes to 1,3-butadiene under an anaerobic condition. It has been reported that an allylic intermediate is formed during both the isomerization and dehydrogenation of butenes [14,16]. The isomerized product is generated by the reinsertion of the abstracted hydrogen, whereas the dehydrogenated product is formed by a further abstraction of hydrogen with yielding water [16]. It has been also reported that sec-butyl cation is generated as an intermediate over acidic sites of alumina at low temperatures, whereas an allylic intermediate is formed over basic sites of alumina at relatively high temperatures [14]. In the isomerization reaction, the formation of cis-2-butene is favored when the sec-butyl cation is generated, while trans-2-butene would be preferred if the allylic intermediate is formed [14]. In our results, the selectivity for trans-2-butene over Al2O3 increased with an increase in the temperature, and trans-2-butene was preferred to cis-2-butene at 200°C (Fig. 4). Therefore, we proposed reaction paths for dehydrogenation and isomerization of butenes over CuO/Al2O3, as shown in Fig. 8 . We infer that the allylic intermediate is formed at a basic site of alumina and hydrogen is then further abstracted through the generation of water with the oxygen of copper oxide. We also examined the catalytic performance of CuO/Al2O3 at an early reaction time during the dehydrogenation of 1-butene in an effort to confirm the highest obtainable catalytic activity according to the oxygen depletion of CuO/Al2O3. Both conversion of 1-butene (66%) and yield of 1,3-butadiene (23%) were significantly enhanced without CO x as a byproduct at an early reaction time (2min), as shown in Fig. 9 . Moreover, recyclability of CuO/Al2O3 catalyst was examined, in order to confirm that the used catalyst has the catalytic activity again by being oxidized. Fig. 10 shows the catalytic performance of CuO/Al2O3 in the 2nd–6th cycles of the dehydrogenation of 1-butene at 200°C after a 5min reaction. The used catalyst was oxidized at 500°C for 30min under a flow of air between each cycle. Conversion of 1-butene and yield for 1,3-butadiene hardly changed, implying that CuO/Al2O3 catalyst which is fully oxidized has an excellent recyclability in the dehydrogenation of 1-butene. Therefore, it can be inferred that CuO/Al2O3 has great potential for use in an anaerobic dehydrogenation process with a short contact time using a moving bed. 4 Conclusions CuO/Al2O3 was used for the dehydrogenation of butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) to 1,3-butadiene at 200°C under an anaerobic condition. It was observed that the oxygen of copper oxide was consumed to generate H2O during the dehydrogenation reaction. Alumina showed excellent activity for the isomerization of butenes. Both copper oxide and alumina were required to produce 1,3-butadiene selectively by activating the C−H bond over alumina and by providing oxygen from the copper oxide. From these results, it is concluded that CuO/Al2O3 has suitable bifunctionality for the dehydrogenation of butenes without the formation of CO x . References [1] V.K. Srivastava M. Maiti R.V. coredata.dc:description: CuO/Al2O3 was used for dehydrogenation of butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) to 1,3-butadiene at 200°C under an anaerobic condition without an excessive amount of dilution. 1,3-butadiene was selectively obtained from butenes without the formation of carbon oxides over the CuO/Al2O3 catalyst. Bifunctionality of oxidation and C−H bond activation by CuO and Al2O3, respectively, were strongly required for the selective conversion of the butenes to 1,3-butadiene.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydrogenation of butenes over copper oxide supported on alumina under anaerobic conditions: Bifunctionality of the catalyst
